sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using block matrices
message_1:
Consider the following system of linear equations with block matrices: 

$$
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 
1 & -1 & 0 & 2\\ 
-1 & 2 & -1 & -3\\ 
0 & -1 & 1 & 1
\end{array}\right]
\begin{bmatrix}
x \\ y \\ z
\end{bmatrix} = 
\begin{bmatrix}
1 \\ -6 \\ 2
\end{bmatrix}
$$

Find the solution $(x,y,z)$ to this system of linear equations using block matrix methods.
message_2:
To solve the given system of linear equations using block matrix methods, we first need to perform Gaussian elimination to obtain an upper triangular matrix. Then, we can use back-substitution to find the solution.

1. The matrix is already in the form where the first element (1,1) is a pivot.
2. Add the first row to the second row to eliminate the element in position (2,1):

$$
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 
1 & -1 & 0 & 2\\ 
0 & 1 & -1 & -1\\ 
0 & -1 & 1 & 1
\end{array}\right]
$$

3. Add the second row to the third row to eliminate the element in position (3,2):

$$
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 
1 & -1 & 0 & 2\\ 
0 & 1 & -1 & -1\\ 
0 & 0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}\right]
$$

Now we have an upper triangular matrix. Notice that the last row represents the equation 0x + 0y + 0z = 0, which is always true. This means that the system has infinitely many solutions, as there is a free variable (z).

To find the general solution, we can use back-substitution:

1. From the second row, we have y - z = -1, so y = z - 1.
2. From the first row, we have x - y = 2, substituting y = z - 1, we get x - (z - 1) = 2, so x = z + 1.

The general solution is given by:

$$
\begin{bmatrix}
x \\ y \\ z
\end{bmatrix} = 
\begin{bmatrix}
z + 1 \\ z - 1 \\ z
\end{bmatrix}
$$

where z can be any real number.
